subject: Home & DIY
title: Solar Panels Don't Need Direct Sunlight
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Solar Panels Don't Need Direct Sunlight.

hook.text: Germany gets less sun than Alaska, yet it's a top solar energy producer. Clouds don't stop solar panels.

buildup.text: Solar panels convert photons into electricity. Photons arrive in both direct sunlight and diffused cloud light.

discovery.text: On a cloudy day, panels produce 10-25% of their peak output. Over a year, this adds up to significant energy.

twist.text: Extreme heat cuts panel efficiency. Cool, sunny climates like Germany can outperform hot deserts per panel.

climax.text: With batteries, net metering, and falling costs, residential solar pays for itself in 6-10 years in most US states.

punchline.text: Panels work with light, not just sunshine.

quiz.question: Why can solar panels in cool climates outperform those in hot deserts?
options: Cool air makes panels spin faster
